overview: This subject will address current topics in the area of physical climate science. Topics will vary from year to year depending on developments in the field but may focus on new research discoveries, areas of scientific debate, or recent climate events. The subject brings together knowledge from previous studies in climate science and related areas to discuss and critically analyse up to date knowledge of the field and its application to the world around us.
ilo: Explain current research topics in several areas of atmospheric, oceanic and climate science;
Synthesise and interpret the current literature in the area of atmospheric, oceanic and climate science;
Judge and assess scientific evidence in cases of ambiguity or conflicting arguments;
Evaluate interrelationships between different drivers of atmospheric and oceanic processes;
Convey complex theories and arguments using clear and concise oral and written communication.
generic_skills: the ability to exercise critical judgement;
adopting a problem-solving approach to complex or ambiguous questions;

Prerequisites.content: This subject is a capstone requirement and should be taken towards the end of the course along with either the Climate Science Industry Project or Climate Science Research Project.

assessment.brief: Participation in weekly two-hour workshops to discuss papers identified by the cohort. Students are assessed on active participation (e.g. taking part in discussions, asking and answering questions) in workshops
assessment.hurdle: Attendance at 7 of 10 workshops is required.

date_times.contact_hours: 24 contact hours: 10 x 2 hours workshops + 1 x 4 hours group presentations
